ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral symmetric slight to severe high-frequency hearing loss consistent with presbycusis and noise exposure.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess speech reception and word recognition abilities.
Verify hearing aid output against prescriptive targets.
Evaluate hearing aid performance with live music (tambourine).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometric evaluation revealed a bilateral symmetric slight to severe sensorineural hearing loss, sharply falling beyond 500 Hz, consistent with presbycusis and noise exposure. Speech understanding was excellent. Middle ear function was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral symmetric slight to severe SNHL, sharply falling beyond 500 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 30 dB HL, Left 25 dB HL. WRS: 100% at 60 dB HL bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflex Thresholds (ART)
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral ARTs consistent with audiometric thresholds. Contralateral ARTs not performed due to equipment limitations.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE)
tests.result_summary: Responses present up to 1,000 Hz; absent above 1,000 Hz.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Hearing aids were fitted with gain matching NAL-NL1 targets. However, the patient reported significant distortion ('fuzzy', 'distorted') when playing the tambourine. This was identified as front-end clipping due to the high peak input level (110 dB SPL) exceeding the A/D converter's dynamic range.

tests.name: Real Ear Measurement (REM)
tests.result_summary: Measured REIG closely matched NAL-NL1 targets for 50, 65, and 75 dB SPL inputs.

tests.name: Subjective Music Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Tambourine sound reported as 'useless' and 'distorted'. Peak input SPL measured at 110 dB SPL, exceeding the hearing aid input limit (~95 dB SPL).

proposed_items: Fit hearing aids with higher input dynamic range (e.g., post-16-bit architecture or analog compressor before A/D converter)
Utilize 'low-cut' microphone settings (-6 dB/octave) to reduce input sensitivity
Use hearing protection during high-volume performances
counseling_actions: Explain 'front-end' distortion: the tambourine's peak input (110 dB SPL) exceeds the hearing aid's A/D converter limit (~95 dB SPL)
Use the 'doorway' analogy: the signal is too tall to fit through the digital entrance without clipping
Reassure that the hearing aids are not broken but require specific technology for high-input music
Counsel on the nature of high-frequency hearing loss and the importance of hearing protection

escalation.rationale_short: Continue management with appropriate technology selection for music.

follow_up_plan.objective: Fit appropriate technology and verify resolution of music sound quality issues.
